journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: System performance tests and start transient analysis of a liquid rocket engine turbopump

contrib-group.aff: Korea Aerospace Research Institute, Daejeon, Korea

author-notes.corresp: Soon-Sam Hong, Korea Aerospace Research Institute, Daejeon, 305-333, Korea. Email: sshong@kari.re.kr

abstract.p: This article describes a series of development tests of a turbopump, which can be applied to a gas generator cycle rocket engine with liquid oxygen and kerosene propellants. A turbine drives both an oxidizer pump and a fuel pump in the turbopump assembly. In the tests, liquid oxygen and kerosene are supplied to the oxidizer pump and the fuel pump, respectively, while either cold hydrogen gas or hot gas from the gas generator is supplied to the turbine. The turbopump is operated reliably at both on-design and off-design conditions, meeting all the performance requirements. The test results are compared with those of the turbopump component tests, where model fluids are used, that is, water for the oxidizer pump and the fuel pump, and cold air for the turbine. The turbopump tests results agree well with the turbopump component test results. The speed buildup of the turbopump at start period is calculated when pressurized gas is used to initially spin the turbine. A differential equation which represents the torque balance between the turbine and the pumps is solved. The calculation shows a good agreement with the test result. When the mechanical loss of the turbopump is considered, a better estimation is obtained.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In a gas generator cycle engine, turbopump development involves the following steps in the test campaign: (i) turbopump component tests, which consist of pump tests and turbine tests, (ii) turbopump assembly tests, and (iii) turbopump hot-fire tests, that is, bootstrap mode tests of the turbopump and gas generator. The turbine gas type for the turbopump assembly tests is either hot or cold gas.1–5 Gribben et al.1 performed both turbopump assembly test and turbopump hot-fire test. They used cold gas for the low speed run and hot gas for the full speed run during the turbopump assembly test. In expander cycle engines,6–10 turbopump hot-fire tests are not necessary, and therefore cold gas is used for the turbopump assembly test. Cold hydrogen gas was used in a test of the fuel turbopump for an LE-7A engine, which is a staged combustion cycle engine, and a full load run was accomplished by increasing the turbine pressure ratio.11 The test results from the cold gas run were compared with those from the conventional hot gas run, and it was found that there was a small difference in the turbine efficiency but no difference in the pump performance.11

The turbopump under investigation is applicable to a gas generator cycle liquid rocket engine with about 300 kN thrust.12 The propellants are liquid oxygen and kerosene. The turbopump is composed of an oxidizer pump, a fuel pump, and a turbine. The turbopump passed through the four stages of the development test procedure which is shown in Figure 1. In the first stage, the turbopump component tests are performed using model fluids. In the pump component tests, the pump is driven by an electric motor at about 50% of full speed and cold water is used as the working fluid.13,14 The characteristics of head-flow, efficiency-flow, cavitation performance, and axial thrust are obtained from the pump component tests. In the turbine component test, the turbine power is measured by a hydraulic dynamometer and cold air is used as the working fluid.15 The characteristics of the efficiency-velocity ratio are obtained from the turbine component test. In the second stage, the turbopump assembly test (TPA test) is performed using the real propellant, that is, liquid oxygen and kerosene to validate the operability of the oxidizer pump and the fuel pump with real propellant. High-pressure cold hydrogen gas is supplied to the turbine to drive the turbopump assembly at full speed. In the third stage, a turbopump-gas generator open-loop test (GG test) is performed to validate the gas generator operability using the propellants which are supplied by the turbopump. In this stage, the gas from the gas generator is not flowed into the turbopump but discharged to the atmosphere. Up to this stage, the turbopump is driven by high-pressure cold hydrogen gas. In the fourth stage, a turbopump-gas generator closed-loop test (TPA-GG test) is conducted. It is not until this stage that the turbopump is driven by the gas which is produced by the gas generator combustion. The objective of the TPA-GG test is to check the operating reliability and performance of the turbopump when the turbopump is run under conditions simulating engine system operation, including chill-down, startup, and shutdown. The authors put more stress on the turbopump itself than on the gas generator. Figure 1.
Turbopump development test procedure.
TPA: turbopump assembly; GG: gas generator.

Startup is an important issue during the development of an engine. Engine thrust buildup follows turbopump speed buildup, therefore understanding of the startup characteristics of a turbopump is crucial to predict the start transient of a rocket engine.16–20 There are four kinds of energy storage systems that supply initial drive power for the turbine: liquid propellant main tanks, pressurized-gas start tanks, pressurized-liquid-propellant start tanks, and solid-propellant start cartridges.21,22 Pressurized-gas start system utilizes high-pressure gas (for example, nitrogen, helium, hydrogen) from a separate tank to initially spin the turbine until the gas generator provides enough gas to drive the turbine. In this study, where hydrogen was used as the pressurized gas, a simple calculation to estimate the speed buildup of the turbopump at start period is carried out.

The first objective of this article is to present the results of a series of development tests for a turbopump. The results of TPA test and the TP-GG test are analyzed and compared with the test results of the turbopump components. The second objective is to estimate the speed buildup of the turbopump in the TPA-GG test in case of pressurized-gas start system, and then the calculation result is compared with the test result.

sec.title: Turbopump features and component-test condition
sec.p:
An oxidizer pump, a fuel pump, and a turbine are united on one axis in the turbopump under investigation. Considering cavitation performances and fuel-rich gas on turbine side, the oxidizer pump is located at one end of the shaft to have an axial inlet and the fuel pump in the middle having a radial inlet. The oxidizer pump is composed of a three-bladed inducer, a shrouded centrifugal impeller with nine blades, and a volute; its stage specific speed is 0.566 (1550 US units of gpm, ft, r/min). The fuel pump is also composed of a three-bladed inducer, a shrouded centrifugal impeller with nine blades, and a volute; its stage specific speed is 0.250 (685 US units of gpm, ft, r/min). The open-cycle engine leads the turbine to employ single stage impulse type. The turbine has circumferentially distributed fourteen convergent-divergent nozzles. Three of the nozzles are prepared for a starter to initiate the turbopump rotation in the engine operation. The pressure ratio of the turbine is 14. Figure 2 shows the turbopump, which is assembled with the gas generator. The nominal operating condition of the turbopump is presented in Table 1. Figure 2.
Turbopump and gas generator for test.
Table 1.
Nominal condition (NC) of turbopump operation.
Item Unit Oxidizer pump Fuel pump Turbine
Flow rate kg/s 64.0 28.5 4.2
Inlet pressure MPa 0.48 0.28 4.9
Outlet pressure MPa 9.6 14.4 0.35
Inlet temperature K 95 288 900
Rotational speed r/min 19,410 19,410 19,410

Before the turbopump assembly tests, component tests for the pumps and the turbine were performed using model fluids (water for the pumps and cold air for the turbine) at about half of the full speed. The validity of the component tests is checked here. Geometric similarity and dynamic similarity need to be satisfied in order to obtain meaningful data from model tests of turbomachinery. First of all, the geometric similarity is satisfied in the present component tests because full-scale of pumps and turbine are used. The dynamic similarity is composed of Reynolds number, Mach number, and flow angle. First, Reynolds number has negligible effect if it is higher than a million.23 Reynolds number, which is based on the wheel tip speed and the rotor diameter, for the pumps and turbine in the present component tests is higher than ten million, and therefore, its effect is considered negligible. Second, Mach number effect at the turbine is considered negligible because Mach number at the inlet of the turbine rotor is the same between the turbine component test and the turbopump assembly test. Third, flow angle at the inlet of the pumps and the turbine is the same between the component test and the turbopump assembly test. Flow coefficient is regulated at the pump test and velocity ratio is regulated at the turbine test in order to adjust the flow angle. In summary, the geometric and dynamic similarities are satisfied in the present component tests, therefore, it is expected that the performance results be the same between the component tests and the turbopump assembly test.

sec.title: Test facility and test procedure
sec.p:
The schematic of the TPA test is shown in Figure 3. Liquid oxygen is supplied to the oxidizer pump from the propellant-supply tank and then it is discharged to the propellant-catch tank; likewise, kerosene is supplied to the fuel pump. The cold hydrogen gas for driving the turbine is supplied from high pressure hydrogen gas bottles. The cold gas discharged from the turbine outlet is sent to an after-burner and then burned out there. To control the flow rate of the pumps, a throttle valve and an orifice are installed downstream of the fuel pump, while three orifices are installed for the oxidizer pump. Figure 3.
Schematic of TPA test.
TPA: turbopump assembly.

The schematic of the TPA-GG test is shown in Figure 4. The hot gas for driving the turbine is produced by a gas generator (GG). A line is branched off from each pump outlet pipe and the line is connected to the gas generator, where the supplied propellants are combusted. A throttle valve and a flow meter are installed on each branched line to control the mixture ratio of the gas generator. The mixture ratio of the gas generator is kept constant so that the temperature of the fuel-rich hot gas from the gas generator can be maintained at 900 K. A feedback control of the turbopump speed is accomplished by regulating the fuel line throttle valve of the gas generator. The hot gas discharged from the turbine outlet is sent to an after-burner and then burned out there like the TPA test. In order to start up the turbopump, pressurized cold hydrogen gas is supplied to the turbine for about 1.5 s at the start. Figure 4.
Schematic of TPA-GG test.
TPA-GG: turbopump assembly-gas generator.

Pressure and temperature are measured at the inlet and outlet of the pumps and the turbine. A few turbine-type flow meters are installed in series upstream of each pump. Accelerometers are installed on the casing of the turbopump and the gas generator, and fast-response pressure transducers are installed at the pump outlets and in the gas generator. A photograph of the turbopump and gas generator under test is presented in Figure 5. It was taken after a TPA-GG test was completed. The turbopump stands vertically and the gas generator is connected to the turbine inlet. The oxidizer pump is located at the top and the turbine at the bottom. Figure 5.
Configuration of TPA-GG test.
TPA-GG: turbopump assembly-gas generator.

Table 2 shows the turbopump operating points, which are derived from the engine-system operating envelope. The turbopump should meet the reliability and performance requirements not only at the nominal condition (NC) but also at four off-design conditions (OD). Table 3 provides a part of TPA and TPA-GG test campaigns for the turbopump under investigation. In the Test Nos. 1 and 2, three operating points were tested in order to conduct the tests economically. Table 2.
Operating points of turbopump (normalized by NC).
Item NC OD1 OD2 OD3 OD4
Rotational speed 1.00 0.95 0.98 1.06 1.02
Flow rate of oxidizer pump 1.00 0.92 0.98 1.09 1.02
Flow rate of fuel pump 1.00 1.00 0.91 1.02 1.11
Discharge pressure of oxidizer pump 1.00 0.91 0.96 1.10 1.05
Discharge pressure of fuel pump 1.00 0.89 0.98 1.13 1.02
NC: nominal condition; OD: off-design condition.
Table 3.
Condition of TPA test and TPA-GG test.
Test no. Test type Oxidizer pump medium Fuel pump medium Turbine medium Operating point Time interval (s)
NC 25
1 TPA test Liquid oxygen Kerosene Hydrogen gas OD4 25
OD3 25
NC 60
2 TPA-GG test Liquid oxygen Kerosene GG gas OD1 30
OD2 30
TPA: turbopump assembly; GG: gas generator; NC: nominal condition; OD: off-design condition.

sec.title: Test results
sec.p: The turbopump was reliably operated in the two test cases of Table 3, meeting the performance requirements. Here are presented the results of a TPA test case (Test No. 1) and a TPA-GG test case (Test No. 2).

sec.title: Distribution of measurement parameters at TPA/TPA-GG tests
sec.p:
In a TPA test (Test No. 1), the test duration of each operating point is 25 s. Time data of rotational speed, oxidizer pump flow rate, and fuel pump flow rate are shown in Figure 6, where it is observed that the data vary with the operating point. When the operating point changes, the control parts (pressure of hydrogen gas supply, throttles to the gas generator, orifice valves at the oxidizer pump outlet, throttle at the fuel pump outlet, and others) start to change simultaneously. The pressure of the hydrogen gas is increased from NC to OD3. For the oxidizer pump, two orifices are open at NC and OD4, while all three orifices are open at OD3. For the fuel pump, the open percentage of the throttle is increased from NC to OD4, while the percentage is decreased from OD4 to OD3. Time data of the fuel pump outlet pressure, the oxidizer pump outlet pressure, and the turbine inlet pressure are shown in Figure 7. The measured parameters in Figures 6 and 7 are flat at steady state of each operating point. Figure 6.
Rotational speed and pump flow rate at TPA test (Test No. 1).
TPA: turbopump assembly.
Figure 7.
Pressure of pumps and turbine at TPA test (Test No. 1).
TPA: turbopump assembly.

In a TPA-GG test (Test No. 2), the test durations at operating points NC, OD1, and OD2 are 60 s, 30 s, and 30 s, respectively. Time data of rotational speed, oxidizer pump flow rate, and fuel pump flow rate are shown in Figure 8. For the oxidizer pump, one orifice is open at OD1, while two orifices are open at NC and OD2. For the fuel pump, the open percentage of the throttle is increased from NC to OD1, while the percentage is decreased from OD1 to OD2. Peaks of the rotational speed observed at the transition of operating points are generated in the process of the feedback control of the rotational speed. The peaks of flow rate and pressure of the pumps are also observed at the transition period. The peaks in the TPA-GG test are larger than those of the TPA test because feedback control of the rotational speed is used in TPA-GG tests while it is not used in TPA tests. It is noted that hydrogen gas of the preset level of pressure is supplied to the turbine inlet in TPA tests. Time data of the turbine inlet temperature, the fuel pump outlet pressure, the oxidizer pump outlet pressure, and the turbine inlet pressure are presented in Figure 9. The turbine inlet temperature was maintained constant at 900 K during the test except during the transition period, which implies the mixture ratio of the gas generator was also kept constant as planned. Figure 8.
Rotational speed and pump flow rate at TPA-GG test (Test No. 2).
TPA-GG: turbopump assembly-gas generator.
Figure 9.
Pressure and temperature of pumps and turbine at TPA-GG test (Test No. 2).
TPA-GG: turbopump assembly-gas generator.

sec.title: Comparison of turbopump performance of TPA/TPA-GG tests with component tests
sec.p:
Performance results of a TPA test (Test No. 1) and a TPA-GG test (Test No. 2) are compared with the turbopump component tests results. As for the pumps, the comparison is made on the chart of head coefficient versus flow coefficient as shown in Figure 10. The results of the TPA test and the TPA-GG test are represented by symbols and those of the pump component tests, where water is used as the working fluid, are represented by lines. The turbopump component test, the TPA test, and the TPA-GG test show good agreement in Figure 10. As for the fuel pump, the difference between the head coefficient of the TPA/TPA-GG tests and that of the component test is less than 1%. As for the oxidizer pump, however, the head coefficient of the TPA/TPA-GG tests was lower than that of component test by about 3.5%. The pump head from the cryogenic fluid test is normally a little lower than that from the water test because there is more leakage (through the clearances between the rotating and stationary parts of the pump) for cryogenic fluid due to its lower viscosity. The kinematic viscosity of liquid oxygen is only about one sixth of that of water. At the same reference flow rate, which is measured at the inlet pipe line of the pump, the actual flow through the pump impeller is larger for the case of low viscosity. Therefore the pump operated in low viscosity fluid has low head, considering the head-flow curve of the pump. In Kamijo and Hirata,24 the pump head from liquid nitrogen test is also lower than that from the water test, when the difference in impeller diameter is considered. Figure 10.
Comparison of pump head (Test Nos. 1 and 2).
TPA-GG: turbopump assembly-gas generator.

As for the turbine, the TPA/TPA-GG test results are compared with the component test results on the chart of efficiency ratio (efficiency normalized by a design value) versus velocity ratio (u/cis) as shown in Figure 11. The design value of the turbine efficiency used for the normalization is the same for the component, TPA, and TPA-GG tests. In the component test, the turbine is run in a cold air environment. The turbine efficiency obtained from the component test is represented as lines in Figure 11. On the other hand, the turbine efficiency from the TPA/TPA-GG test, which is represented as symbols in the figure, is defined as the ratio of the power consumed by the two pumps to the turbine adiabatic power in the tests. The properties of hydrogen gas and GG gas are used for TPA test and TPA-GG test, respectively, to calculate the turbine adiabatic power. (1)(mcpT1(1-(p2p1)γ-1γ)η)tb =(QΔpη)po+ (QΔpη)pf Figure 11.
Comparison of turbine efficiency (Test Nos. 1 and 2).
TPA-GG: turbopump assembly-gas generator.

The pump efficiency values used in equation (1) are obtained from the component tests. It is noted that the right hand side of equation (1) is measured by a hydraulic dynamometer in the turbine component test. A property (specific heat ratio) of hot gas from the gas generator is a little different from that of cold hydrogen gas, and therefore the efficiency curves of turbine component tests are different from each other in the figure. In Figure 11, the turbine efficiency ratio from the TPA test was lower than that of the component test by 2%, and the turbine efficiency ratio from the TPA-GG test was lower than that of the component test by 2.5–3%. The difference of turbine efficiency between the TPA test and the component test is considered to be the mechanical loss in the turbopump, and this is the case for the TPA-GG test as well. The turbine efficiency level from the TPA test is much lower than that of the TPA-GG test because the velocity ratio of the TPA test is lower. Kinefuchi et al.11 tested the fuel turbopump of LE-7A rocket engine using both the cold hydrogen gas and the typical hydrogen-rich hot gas, and they found that the difference in the turbine efficiency between the cold run and the hot run was small. It is noted that the specific heat ratio of the cold hydrogen gas is similar to that of the hydrogen-rich hot gas. In their test,11 the velocity ratio ranged from 0.31 to 0.33 in the cold run and from 0.33 to 0.36 in the hot run. However, as for the turbopump under investigation, there is a large difference in the velocity ratio between the TPA test and the TPA-GG test; the velocity ratio ranged from 0.13 to 0.14 in the TPA test but it ranged from 0.26 to 0.28 in the TPA-GG test. Therefore the difference in the turbine efficiency level between TPA test and TPA-GG test was large.

sec.title: Calculation of rotational speed of turbopump at start period
sec.p:
The rotational speed of the turbopump at start period is calculated, and the result for the case of Test No. 2 is presented here. The calculating procedure is given in Appendix 2. The test results of the turbine inlet pressures and rotational speed at start period of Test No. 2 are shown in Figure 12. Cold hydrogen gas from the starter is supplied quickly to the starter manifold at the turbine from beginning to Time = 1.7 s. High-temperature gas from the gas generator is supplied to the gas generator manifold of the turbine from about Time = 0.9 s. Then the power source which is supplied to the turbine up to Time = 0.9 s is the starter gas only. Figure 12.
Test results of turbine inlet pressure and rotational speed at start period (Test No. 2).

The rotational speed is calculated for 0.9 s at start period (Time = 0–0.9 s) by using the equations (2)–(9) of Appendix 2. The turbine efficiency in equation (5) is obtained from the turbine component test. The proportional factors for the pump torque in equations (8) and (9) are derived by using the pump efficiency which is obtained from the component test. Equation (2) is solved by a numerical technique, which is the well-known Euler method in this study. The temperature (T1) and the pressure (p1) of the turbine starter manifold and the turbine outlet pressure (p2) are given. The calculated rotational speed for the case of Test No. 2 is shown in Figure 13. Two kinds of calculation condition are considered: one without mechanical loss and the other with mechanical loss in the turbopump. Mechanical loss is not considered in equation (2); however, there is mechanical loss in Figure 11. The mechanical loss in TPA test in Figure 11 is about 2% of pump power, therefore, 2% of mechanical loss is considered in the case of the calculation with mechanical loss. Calculation with mechanical loss is closer to the test result at Time = 0.5–0.9 in Figure 13. The calculation shows good agreement with the test result. The calculation method in this study is simple but can be used to estimate the speed buildup of the turbopump at start period. Figure 13.
Calculation of rotational speed at start period (Test No. 2).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: A series of development tests were performed for a turbopump, which can be applied to a gas generator cycle LOX/kerosene engine with about 300 kN thrust. Turbopump assembly (TPA) test and turbopump-gas generator (TPA-GG) test were conducted at full speed using real propellants, that is, liquid oxygen and kerosene. One test case from the TPA tests and another test case from the TPA-GG tests are described in detail. The turbopump was run at three operating points in each test case. The turbopump was successfully operated during tests at both on-design and off-design points, and it met the performance requirements in both. The test results of the TPA test and the TPA-GG test are compared with those of turbopump component tests in terms of turbopump performance. As for the fuel pump, the difference of the head coefficient between the TPA/TPA-GG tests and the component test was less than 1%. As for the oxidizer pump, the head coefficient of the TPA/TPA-GG tests was lower than that of the component test by about 3.5%, which arises from the lower viscosity of the cryogenic fluid. As for the turbine, the efficiency of the TPA/TPA-GG tests was lower than that of the component test by 2–3%, and the difference is considered to be the mechanical loss in the turbopump. The above results can be a data base to use the performance scaling laws for the design of a turbopump.

The buildup of the rotational speed of the turbopump at start period is calculated by solving a simple differential equation which represents the torque balance between the turbine and the pumps. Pressurized hydrogen gas is used to initially spin the turbine in this study. The pressure and the temperature of the starter manifold at the turbine inlet and the turbine outlet pressure are given, and then the equation is solved by a numerical method. The calculation shows a good agreement with the test result. When the mechanical loss is considered, the calculation shows a better result. The calculation method presented in this study is simple but seems to be useful to estimate the speed buildup of the turbopump at start period.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

def.p: hub-tip flow passage area at inducer inlet
moment of inertia of rotating parts of turbopump
pitch line velocity of turbine rotor
inlet tip speed of pump inducer
outlet tip speed of pump impeller

sec.title: Appendix 2
sec.p: The angular velocity ω of a turbopump at start period can be found after solving the following equation, which relates the angular acceleration and the torque difference of the turbopump. (2)Idωdt=τtb-τpo-τpf where I is the moment of inertia of rotating parts of turbopump, τtb the torque produced by the turbine, τpo the torque absorbed by the oxidizer pump, τpf the torque absorbed by the fuel pump.

The turbine torque τtb is calculated by the following equation (3)τtb=1ωmcpT1(1-(p2p1)γ-1γ)η where m is the mass flow rate of turbine, cp the constant-pressure specific heat, T1 the turbine inlet temperature, p1 the turbine inlet pressure, p2 the turbine outlet pressure, γ the specific heat ratio, η the turbine efficiency. The turbine mass flow rate is calculated from the choking condition at the turbine nozzle of the starter (4)m=cdA*p1T1γR(2γ+1)γ+1γ-1 cd is the discharge coefficient of the nozzle, A* the cross-sectional area of the nozzle throat, R the specific gas constant. The turbine efficiency is the function of the velocity ratio u/cis. (5)η=f(u/cis) where u is the pitch line velocity of the turbine rotor and cis the isentropic velocity. They are defined by the following equations (6)u=ωd2 (7)cis=2γRγ-1T1(1-(p2p1)γ-1γ) where d is the mean diameter of the turbine rotor.

The torque absorbed by the pumps is proportional to the square of the angular velocity and the proportional factors (apo and apf) are determined on the basis of the nominal operating condition of the turbopump. (8)τpo=apoω2 (9)τpf=apfω2
